title: How long can I use an Android smartphone? - Quora

response.answer_text: From a purely technical standpoint, your smartphone will work as long as nothing goes wrong with it, or it becomes obsolete. Here, I won’t equate old technology with obsolescence since a lot of us use really old 2G feature phones and are fine with it. So here goes - Battery Life - All batteries have what are called charge cycles ie the number of times the battery is charged and discharged. As the charge cycles build up, the ability of the battery to hold charge diminishes and the battery’s performance falls.  At a point of time, you have to change the battery. Nowadays, you can’t change batteries yourself as these are locked into the phone and the back cover isn’t removable. So you have to take it to a service center. But service centers won’t keep batteries of devices over 1–2 years old (at most). If your device dies after this time has elapsed, you might as well sing its swansong. But note that some devices, like my Samsung Galaxy Y Duos, is chugging along even though it is far older. That said, I haven’t heard of anyone being able to maintain reliable battery performance on a daily driver for longer than 4–5 years. So that’s one limiting factor.Display - The display of a device is also prone to getting weaker over time. In  some cases, the display will give up working in 3–4 years, though this is not common. More likely you’ll end up with weird tints and dead pixels like you find in old TV sets, but that doesn’t make the phone unusable.Internal Memory - Like charge cycles, memory has write cycles. These are the times when you write stuff afresh onto a certain block of memory. Over time, some sections become unusable. In layman’s terms, we say that the memory is corrupted and unusable. If your core device files end up in these corrupted sectors (or get corrupted otherwise), you may have to do a system reset. But if it’s bad enough, that may not help. Your phone gets “bricked” and you have to get a new one. Can’t set a timetable for this, because I’ve seen memory get corrupted in as less as a year. But usually, memory corruption doesn’t set in faster than  battery weakening.Network obsolescence - This will happen, but hasn’t happened anywhere, to any smartphone, yet. Each smartphone has a radio that manages to connect to certain frequencies. Depending on what the tech behind those frequencies are, we call them 2G, 3G, 4G and recently, 5G. Over time, you’d expect networks to shift entirely to shift to say 3G or 4G, and dispose of old technologies. These may make very old smartphones obsolete because the radio won’t be able to find those frequencies anymore. But as I said, this hasn’t happened yet, and wont’ happen till we’ve probably hit a couple more generations.Damage - Obviously, if the damage is severe enough, you can’t use the device anymore.Those were some of the ways  in which you may be forced to stop using your smartphone. Note that I’ve listed them in decreasing order of frequency, with 1 being most frequent and 4 being completely hypothetical. 5,  of course, can happen anytime unless you’re careful. Hope this helps!
